items.title: We asked CBC's president: Is CBC carrying out an 'ideological objective'?
items.description: Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre and other critics of the CBC and Radio-Canada have said Canada's public broadcaster has an 'ideological objective.' The CBC's Front Burner sat down with the president of the public broadcaster, Marie-Philippe Bouchard, and asked her to weigh in.

items.title: Over 60% of people in Manitoba's ankle monitoring program were rearrested or breached rules
items.description: More than half the people released with an ankle monitor since those devices were introduced in Manitoba in August 2024 were rearrested or broke the rules of their release while wearing one, recent numbers obtained by CBC News show.

items.title: How Certified Canadian Publishers Keep Our Stories Close to Home
items.description: A new national program helps readers easily spot and support Canadian-owned book publishers.

items.title: An inside look at how London, Ont., police go from seizing illegal guns to finding out how they got here
items.description: With the number of reported shootings in London, Ont., reaching 20 in 2025, the police service says it's working tirelessly to pinpoint where illegal firearms are coming from and take them off the streets. Officials gave CBC London an inside look at how that process begins and how investigators learn about everything from the owner’s identity to a weapon’s origin.

items.title: BC’s Government Employee Strike Is Over. Here’s What Comes Next
items.description: The tentative deal clears the way for other public sector unions to fight for better wages.

items.title: Saskatchewan food banks seeing 5% increase in demand, report says
items.description: Saskatchewan food banks say they are seeing an increase in demand, as a new nationwide report points to an uptick in food bank clients across the country.

items.title: B.C. opening forest trade office in U.K., will run anti-tariff ads online
items.description: British Columbia's government says it is opening a "forest trade office" in London, U.K., in an effort to boost exports to Europe.

items.title: What's next for Calgary's municipal political parties?
items.description: Calgarians elected six city councillors who affiliated with a party during the 2025 election campaign including four candidates from the Communities First party.

items.title: The Beaches make a play for Canadian rock royalty at Doug Mitchell
items.description: The Beaches are making more than just waves.

items.title: BC Residents May Have to Cover a Property Tax Break for Pipelines
items.description: After lobbying, BC Assessment slashed its appraisals of the industry’s infrastructure.

items.title: Which industry in each province is most threatened by tariffs?
items.description: As tariffs make an impact, Canadian industries are finding themselves competing for priority in trade negotiations. Here are the industries under threat in each province.

items.title: 'Very sad and tragic': Humpback whale found dead off Keats Island, B.C.
items.description: An investigation is underway to determine what happened to the four-year-old humpback whale named Wisp.

items.title: Report outlines how Indigenous survivors of coerced sterilization can pursue new pregnancies
Get live results from the Nunavut election
